channel.title: Sound in the universe
channel.description:
I have a hard question here its not for school but its also different then many asked.
When the big bang happened, do you think if a person or something else was a live (in theory not truly) could have herd it, like as in sound waves?

item.title: Sound in the universe
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“noobs are ftw, post:23, topic:343292”][quote author=The Reaper X link=topic=439685.msg3231311#msg3231311 date=1276098278]
Considering there are no particles for the sound waves to bounce off of, no, there would be no sound.

http://www.qrg.northwestern.edu/projects/vss/docs/space-environment/1-is-there-sound-in-space.html
[/quote]

beat me to it

cj forgot to lock :D[/quote]

I didn’t forget, that was my sluggish internet taking in excess of 20 seconds to load pages.

Read full topic

item.title: Sound in the universe
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“dragonfire455, post:17, topic:343292”][quote author=jmood128 link=topic=439685.msg3232396#msg3232396 date=1276197680]
This is a discussion on if it is possible that if there was something a live it could hear the big bang, not if the big bang is real. I said no religion for a reason also if you don’t believe in it don’t post.

This is a theory on weather it could be possible for sound waves to be made during the big bang, not before or after when the universe expand to the point were sound waves couldn’t be made.
[/quote]It’s hard to hold a intellectual discussion with someone who can’t even spell “whether” right.[/quote]

Well, that should’ve been an not a if you’re gonna be picky.

Read full topic

item.description:
@krackkid wrote:

SilentCJ:

That’d be weird, you see a big boom right in front of you, but it’s silent :o , it’d be like playing COD on mute.

I hate playing CoD on mute, its like wtf. Lol

and I support the big bang(if that is somethign sexual that is)

item.title: Sound in the universe
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

rip4d:

The big bang would make a sound once it reached you because thats where the matter is. However, considering the supposed heat of the big bang, you’d be incinerated before hearing it. The heat was thought to be roughly 10^28°C

Read my post again. I never said anything about a person being there for real its a theory I think we all know that no one could have been there.

[quote=“Slave Scyth, post:1, topic:343406”][img]http://memegenerator.net/Liberal-Douche-Garofalo/ImageMacro/976034/Liberal-Douche-Garofalo-no-prayer-in-school-but-lets-teach-evolution.jpg[/img

Big Bang… never happened.[/quote]

Fuck off.

Read full topic

item.title: Sound in the universe
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

The big bang would make a sound once it reached you because thats where the matter is. However, considering the supposed heat of the big bang, you’d be incinerated before hearing it. The heat was thought to be roughly 10^28°C

item.title: Sound in the universe
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:9, topic:343292”]Just a weird idea popped into my head.
During the explosion of the Big Bang particles expanded out from a specific point. Obviously as they move they must make some sort of contact and “vibrate” so wouldn’t you get a delayed swoosh of noise a couple seconds later.

If that didn’t make any sense, I mean didn’t the Big Bang create particles which consequently vibrated to create noise?[/quote]

I was going to say that,but then I thought some one will be like your a fag your wrong. So I didn’t say anything.

But like Fat Cookies said just think about it, when the big bang happened it send out massive amounts of matter (anti-matter what ever else you want to add) at once mean there were particles for that little amount of time when all the matter in the universe was still right there in abundant amounts.

Read full topic

item.title: Sound in the universe
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Just a weird idea popped into my head.
During the explosion of the Big Bang particles expanded out from a specific point. Obviously as they move they must make some sort of contact and “vibrate” so wouldn’t you get a delayed swoosh of noise a couple seconds later.

If that didn’t make any sense, I mean didn’t the Big Bang create particles which consequently vibrated to create noise?

Read full topic

item.title: Sound in the universe
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

The Reaper X:

Considering there are no particles for the sound waves to bounce off of, no, there would be no sound.

This.

Space is a vacuum; there is nothing for the sound waves to vibrate, therefore we wouldn’t be able to hear it.

Read full topic
